member.name: M:FluorineFx.Messaging.Adapter.ApplicationAdapter.CreateSharedObject(FluorineFx.Messaging.Api.IScope,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Creates a new shared object for given scope. Server-side shared objects (also known as Remote SO) are special kind of objects synchronized between clients.
To get an instance of RSO at client-side, use SharedObject.getRemote().
SharedObjects can be persistent and transient. Persistent RSO are stateful, i.e. store their data between sessions. If you need to store some data on server while clients go back and forth use persistent SO, otherwise perfer usage of transient for extra performance.
member.param: Scope that shared object belongs to.
Whether SharedObject instance should be persistent or not.
member.returns: true if SO was created, false otherwise.

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Messaging.Adapter.ApplicationAdapter.GetSharedObject(FluorineFx.Messaging.Api.IScope,System.String)
member.summary: Returns shared object from given scope by name.
member.param: Scope that shared object belongs to.
member.returns: Shared object instance with the specifed name.

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Messaging.Adapter.ApplicationAdapter.GetSharedObject(FluorineFx.Messaging.Api.IScope,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns shared object from given scope by name.
member.param: Scope that shared object belongs to.
Whether SharedObject instance should be persistent or not.
member.returns: Shared object instance with the specifed name.

member.summary: Checks whether there is a SharedObject with given scope and name.
member.param: Scope that shared object belongs to.
member.returns: true if SharedObject exists, false otherwise.

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Messaging.Adapter.ApplicationAdapter.ClearSharedObjects(FluorineFx.Messaging.Api.IScope,System.String)
member.summary:
Deletes persistent shared objects specified by name and clears all properties from active shared objects (persistent and nonpersistent). The name parameter specifies the name of a shared object, which can include a slash (/) as a delimiter between directories in the path. The last element in the path can contain wildcard patterns (for example, a question mark [?] and an asterisk [*]) or a shared object name. The ClearSharedObjects() method traverses the shared object hierarchy along the specified path and clears all the shared objects. Specifying a slash (/) clears all the shared objects associated with an application instance.
The following values are possible for the soPath parameter:
soPath parameter action
clears all local and persistent shared objects associated with the instance
/foo/bar clears the shared object /foo/bar; if bar is a directory name, no shared objects are deleted
/foo/bar/* clears all shared objects stored under the instance directory
/foo/bar. the bar directory is also deleted if no persistent shared objects are in use within this namespace
/foo/bar/XX?? clears all shared objects that begin with XX, followed by any two characters
If a directory name matches this specification, all the shared objects within this directory are cleared.
If you call the ClearSharedObjects() method and the specified path matches a shared object that is currently active, all its properties are deleted, and a "clear" event is sent to all subscribers of the shared object. If it is a persistent shared object, the persistent store is also cleared.
member.param: Scope that shared object belongs to.

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Util.StringUtils.HasText(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a has text.

remarks.p: More specifically, returns if the string is not , it's is > zero (0), and it has at least one non-whitespace character.

member.param: The string to check, may be .
member.returns: if the is not , > zero (0), and does not consist solely of whitespace.

example.code: StringUtils.HasText(null) = false StringUtils.HasText("") = false StringUtils.HasText(" ") = false StringUtils.HasText("12345") = true StringUtils.HasText(" 12345 ") = true

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Util.StringUtils.HasLength(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a string has length.
member.param: The string to check, may be .
member.returns: if the string has length and is not .

example.code: StringUtils.HasLength(null) = false StringUtils.HasLength("") = false StringUtils.HasLength(" ") = true StringUtils.HasLength("Hello") = true

member.name: M:FluorineFx.FluorineGateway.GetFilterForScheme(System.String[],System.IO.Stream,FluorineFx.Configuration.HttpCompressSettings)
member.summary: Get ahold of a for the given encoding scheme. If no encoding scheme can be found, it returns null.
member.remarks: See http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec14.html#sec14.3 for details on how clients are supposed to construct the Accept-Encoding header. This implementation follows those rules, though we allow the server to override the preference given to different supported algorithms. I'm doing this as I would rather give the server control over the algorithm decision than the client. If the clients send up * as an accepted encoding with highest quality, we use the preferred algorithm as specified in the config file.

member.name: T:FluorineFx.Collections.SetOp
member.summary: Union, intersection, and other operations on sorted sequences.

remarks.para: This class implements efficient operation on sorted sequences: Union, Merge, Intersection, Difference, and SymmetricDifference.
All methods of the class are static
The methods operate on "sorted sequences" which can be any enumerables, provided they are properly sorted. The sequences are allowed to contiain duplicates.

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Collections.SetOp.Union(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IComparer,FluorineFx.Collections.IOutputIterator)
member.summary: Computes union of two sorted sequences.

remarks.para: Both set1 and set2 must be sorted in ascending order with respect to comparer.
Union contains elements present in one or both ranges.
Result is written to the output iterator one member at a time
Union differs from Merge for multisets.

If k equal elements are present in set1 and m elements equal to those k are present in set2,then k elements from set1 are included in the output, followed by max(m-k, 0) elements from set2. The total of max(k,m) are added to the output. If you'd like to have m+k elements, use Merge function.
Complexity: linear on combined number of items in both sequences

example.para: The following elements will be added to output: {"a", "b", "test", "Test", "TEST", "z" }

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Collections.SetOp.Merge(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IComparer,FluorineFx.Collections.IOutputIterator)
member.summary: Computes merge of two sorted sequences.

remarks.para: Both set1 and set2 must be sorted in ascending order with respect to comparer.
Merge contains elements present in one or both ranges.
Result is written to the output iterator one member at a time
Merge differs from Union() for multisets.

If k equal elements are present in set1 and m elements equal to those k are present in set2, then k elements from set1 are included in the output, followed by m elements from set2, for the total of k+m equal elements. If you'd like to have max(k,m) m+k elements, use Union function.
Complexity: linear on combined number of items in both sequences

example.para: The following elements will be added to output: {"a", "b", "test", "Test", "tEst", "teSt", "TEST", "z", "Z" }

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Collections.SetOp.Inersection(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IComparer,FluorineFx.Collections.IOutputIterator)
member.summary: Computes intersection of two sorted sequences.

remarks.para: Both set1 and set2 must be sorted in ascending order with respect to comparer.
Intersection contains elements present in both set1 and set2.
Result is written to the output iterator one member at a time
For multisets, if set1 contains k equal elements, and set2 contains m elements equal to those k, then min(k,m) elements from set1 are included in the output.
Complexity: linear on combined number of items in both sequences

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Collections.SetOp.Difference(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IComparer,FluorineFx.Collections.IOutputIterator)
member.summary: Computes difference of two sorted sequences.

remarks.para: Both set1 and set2 must be sorted in ascending order with respect to comparer.
Difference contains elements present in set1, but not in set2.
Result is written to the output iterator one member at a time
For multisets, if set1 contains k equal elements, and set2 contains m elements equal to those k, then max(k-m,0) elements from set1 are included in the output.
Complexity: linear on combined number of items in both sequences

member.name: M:FluorineFx.Collections.SetOp.SymmetricDifference(System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IEnumerable,System.Collections.IComparer,FluorineFx.Collections.IOutputIterator)
member.summary: Computes symmetric difference (XOR) of two sorted sequences.

remarks.para: Both set1 and set2 must be sorted in ascending order with respect to comparer.
Symmetric difference contains elements present in exactly one set, but not in both.
Result is written to the output iterator one member at a time

For multisets, if set1 contains k equal elements, and set2 contains m elements equal to those k, then if k>=m, k-m last elements from set1 are included in the output. If k<m, m-k last elements from set2 are included in the output.
Complexity: linear on combined number of items in both sequences

member.name: T:FluorineFx.IO.FLV.MetaCue
member.summary:
Cue point is metadata marker used to control and accompany video playback with client-side application events. Each cue point have at least one attribute, timestamp. Timestamp specifies position of cue point in FLV file.
Cue points are usually used as event triggers down video flow or navigation points in a file. Cue points are of two types:
Embedded into FLV or SWF
External, or added on fly (e.g. with FLVPlayback component or ActionScript) on both server-side and client-side.
To add cue point trigger event listener at client-side in Flex/Flash application, use NetStream.onCuePoint event handler.

P:FluorineFx.IO.Bytecode.Lightweight.EmitHelper.cgt
member.summary: Calls ILGenerator.Emit() that compares two values. If the first value is greater than the second, the integer value 1 (int32) is pushed onto the evaluation stack; otherwise 0 (int32) is pushed onto the evaluation stack.

member.name: P:FluorineFx.IO.Bytecode.Lightweight.EmitHelper.cgt_un
member.summary: Calls ILGenerator.Emit() that compares two unsigned or unordered values. If the first value is greater than the second, the integer value 1 (int32) is pushed onto the evaluation stack; otherwise 0 (int32) is pushed onto the evaluation stack.

member.name: P:FluorineFx.IO.Bytecode.Lightweight.EmitHelper.ckfinite
member.summary: Calls ILGenerator.Emit() that throws ArithmeticException if value is not a finite number.

member.name: P:FluorineFx.IO.Bytecode.Lightweight.EmitHelper.clt
member.summary: Calls ILGenerator.Emit() that compares two values. If the first value is less than the second, the integer value 1 (int32) is pushed onto the evaluation stack; otherwise 0 (int32) is pushed onto the evaluation stack.

member.name: P:FluorineFx.IO.Bytecode.Lightweight.EmitHelper.clt_un
member.summary: Calls ILGenerator.Emit() that compares the unsigned or unordered values value1 and value2. If value1 is less than value2, then the integer value 1 (int32) is pushed onto the evaluation stack; otherwise 0 (int32) is pushed onto the evaluation stack.

member.remarks:
If MisfireSmartPolicyEnabled is set to true, then the following scheme will be used:
If the Repeat Count is 0, then the instruction will be interpreted as .
If the Repeat Count is , then the instruction will be interpreted as . WARNING: using MisfirePolicy.SimpleTrigger.RescheduleNowWithRemainingRepeatCount with a trigger that has a non-null end-time may cause the trigger to never fire again if the end-time arrived during the misfire time span.
If the Repeat Count is > 0, then the instruction will be interpreted as .
